Patient: You know I’m just surrounded with just good people taking good care. Doctor: People who care. Here’s what I said about the bike trip. It’s up to him really to be smart about it. You know I know he loves it and this is something he just has to work out by himself and also with you guys. There’s no real medical reason technically and it’s gonna take us a week or two to get that medicine, so there’s time. He says he’s not gonna stay down in F____. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: If he had a four, I’d be comfortable with him being on the bike – Doctor: Yeah, I know.

text: Family Member: If he overdoes it on one day. Doctor: Oh, of course. Oh, everybody does that. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Everybody does that not just you. Patient: Okay. Doctor: You know there’s two philosophies with that which is like oh, if it’s good day I’m gonna max it out so I can veg out the next day and I have some other patients that will just like pace themselves like I know it’s a good day but I don’t want to pay the price the next day so I’ll just moderate myself and then it’s more even. So, it’s really your preference. Some people would just be like I’d rather have one good day out of three rather than my the eh days. Patient: Right, okay. Doctor: So, a lot of people are different in their activity level. You know, some folks are just go, go, go, and some are like Patient: RIght. Doctor: oh, no, I like to chill and be on my computer and watch my TV and get on the phone, you know, so everyone’s activity level. Patient: I like more activity. Doctor: Yeah.

text: Patient: - going down and coming back, and, uh, my daughter said you don’t seem like you feel anything. I said, no, I feel pretty good there. And, uh, so I do have those particular days, but then I have those days as well. I said, oh, man, when this day going to be over with so I can go to bed tonight Doctor: Is that because of pain that those days are hard for you? Patient: Sometimes it’s, it’s pain, but a lot of the areas that I wasn’t haven’t pain in, uh, not much anymore. My heel on my left side was having a lot of pain that I think I had shared, and, uh, I still have some if I go and overdo it, but other than that, no, my shoulders every now and then. My biggest challenge now is, is getting a good night’s sleep. Doctor: Okay. Patient: And that’s because I’ve tried a number of different ways on how to sleep in the bed. I, I have these pillows that I prop up with a long pillow there, to try to lean up against the back of it so, I, you know, my back is up against the pillow. It works some nights. Some nights it doesn’t work. Doctor: Okay. And so you’re having trouble falling asleep or is it that you fall asleep and then you, you’re waking up with-? Patient: Well, I wake back up. And sometimes if, uh, you know how you try to get in a comfortable position? It’s trying to find that comfortable position for that night. Doctor: So you’re waking up because of pain? Patient: Uh, not pain all the time. Sometimes it’s just, uh, what’s the term I’m looking for? Doctor: Discomfort? Patient: Yeah. You know? And, uh, just trying to get in a place where you feel like this is where I need to be at, I’m happy here. So, uh, uh, one of the best sleeping place, and I hate to say it, is my living room downstairs on the couch. I prop the pillows up, and, uh, and got my favorite space, so when I lay down and put my back up right up against the back of it, but I don’t want to be in the business of sleeping on my living room couch every night, either. We have a sleep number bed that we purchased just for this, but, uh, uh, I wouldn’t recommend sleep number being if that’s what you’re going, you’re going to use it for, because it’s not all it’s, it’s cut out to be. You’re paying a lot of money for a bed. And sometimes it works, sometimes it don’t. So my biggest challenge each night is to figure out, okay, what’s going to work tonight? Is my Lazy Boy going to work? Uh, I even tried the floor with my granddaughter’s, uh, what do you call those things she has? Family Member: The bean bag. Patient: The bean bags. That was the worst idea I ever had. When I got in that bean bag, uh, I, I was in pain. And the bad part is I couldn’t get back out of the, get out of the bean bag, and get off the floor.

text: Family Member: So you can radiate? Doctor: We can radiate anywhere. Family Member: So in C___ Dr. F____ can radiate. Doctor: Dr. F____ can radiate it. If it’s needed. Now, he won't just willy nilly do it unless you have pain, or we've shown that everything about you is stable and those are the only two areas that’s acting up. Family Member: Well, that’s good to know that. I didn’t know that. Doctor: Yeah see you’re not just out there. Patient: Now I’ve got a question for you. Doctor: Yeah. Shoot. Patient: Nobody really explained to me what I will feel as this disease progresses- Doctor: Mmm. Patient: -as it changes and that I will detect the symptoms that I will. Doctor: Yeah. Well, the sheer fact that you are actually asking me that tells me that you don't have many symptoms, because people who have the symptoms, be it bone pain or just extreme fatigue or weight Loss, no appetite will tell me, “Oh man, look at all these things happening to me is because of my cancer?” So when you're curious, that means like, okay, none of this stuff is happening, which is great, but you worry about it because you think this is it, I'm gonna get bone pain. And this is it. You know, that's not the case. If you have pain in the bone, there are medicines to help or more importantly, there are techniques like radiation to help and there are other medicines that we can do to and other strategies to help the pain go away. So pain is usually what everybody worries about is number one, and then the other ones would be things like, you know, complete quality of life loss is, “I don't want to anything”

text: Family Member: Spine, ribs, and shoulder? (pause11sec) Doctor: Yeah. The one, the one thing we see also with, we’ve seen with the testosterone, is something called a flair. Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
